title: How to Determine If Your Tarantula Is Molting: The Complete Guide

steps.title: Decreased movement
steps.content: Decreased movement Is your spider moving around less than usual? Tarantulas often stop moving or don't move at all to conserve energy before a molt. If your tarantula has not been moving much lately, then this could be a sign that she is about to molt. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Refusal to eat
steps.content: Refusal to eat Is your tarantula eating? Before a big molt, tarantulas will stop eating for extended periods of time, ranging from a few weeks to a couple of months. If you have noticed that your tarantula has not been eating or that she has been eating less than usual, then this could indicate that she is going to molt soon. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Clear fluid droplets
steps.content: Clear fluid droplets Some tarantulas secrete tiny drops of a clear fluid between the joints on their legs, and this can indicate that your tarantula is getting ready to molt. Check to see if you can see these droplets, but keep in mind that not all tarantulas do this before a molt. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Thinning hair or a bald spot
steps.content: Thinning hair or a bald spot Some tarantulas will lose hair on their abdomens leading up to a molt. You might notice less hair on your tarantula’s abdomen or even a bald spot on your tarantula’s abdomen. [4] X Research source If you see this, then it is a good sign that your tarantula is getting ready to molt. Your tarantula’s abdomen may also appear darker and shinier than usual before she molts. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Being in an upside-down position
steps.content: Being in an upside-down position What position is the spider in? During a molt, a tarantula lays up-side down on her back or on her side to get out of the old skin easier. [6] X Research source This happens when a tarantula is actively molting and the whole process takes just a few hours. If your tarantula is on her back or side, then she might be trying to molt her skin. Spiders curl up their legs tightly underneath them when they die. If your tarantula is on her stomach and has curled her legs tightly inwards, then she may be dead or dying. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Leave your tarantula be.
steps.content: Leave your tarantula be. Tarantulas can sustain injuries or even die if they are disturbed while they are molting. Therefore, it is important to leave your tarantula alone while she molts. [8] X Research source Plan to leave your tarantula while she is showing signs of molting and for at least one week following a molt. Wait at least one week after a molt to pick up and/or hold your tarantula. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the exoskeleton from the cage after your tarantula molts.
steps.content: Remove the exoskeleton from the cage after your tarantula molts. After your tarantula has completely shed her exoskeleton, you can remove it from her cage. Try using a pair of tweezers to pick the exoskeleton up.

steps.title: Skip feedings for three to five days after your tarantula has molted.
steps.content: Skip feedings for three to five days after your tarantula has molted. Your tarantula will be sensitive and prone to injury following a molt, which means that its normal prey might harm her. Therefore, do not feed your tarantula for at least a few days following a molt. [10] X Research source While your tarantula cannot hunt following a molt, she will still need to drink water. Make sure your tarantula has plenty of fresh water at all times. [11] X Research source
